The button would give Google Search users the option to purchase without needing to visit a separate website. The company's chief business officer, Omid Kordestani, emphasized that this feature aims to simplify the shopping process and provide a seamless experience for users. The button, which is currently in beta testing, allows users to directly add items to their cart and check out from the Google Search page itself. Kordestani mentioned that the feature is designed to save time and effort for busy consumers who prefer to shop quickly and efficiently. The integration of this button would also benefit retailers by increasing their visibility and potentially boosting sales through Google's vast user base. However, some critics argue that this could lead to decreased traffic on individual retailers' websites and might impact their ability to build direct relationships with customers. Nevertheless, Google assures that it is working closely with retail partners to ensure a mutually beneficial arrangement. The new feature is expected to roll out widely later this year, and it will be interesting to see how it reshapes the online shopping landscape.

The Black Caps, having been set a world record 504 to win, resumed on 142-3 and their challenge quickly folded. Brendon McCullum, the captain, tried his best to inspire his team with aggressive batting, but wickets continued to fall at regular intervals. The opposition bowlers were relentless, exploiting the pitch conditions and putting constant pressure on the New Zealand batsmen. The middle and lower order failed to provide any substantial resistance, and the team was eventually bowled out for 256. This resulted in a crushing defeat by 247 runs. The loss was a major disappointment for the Black Caps, who had high hopes of chasing down the record target. Despite the defeat, there were some positives to take away, such as the performances of some young players who showed potential. The team will now have to regroup and focus on their upcoming matches, learning from their mistakes and working on their weaknesses.

An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for the past six months, totaling over £100,000 in arrears. The assembly is now considering its options, including potentially terminating the lease agreement if the situation does not improve. Additionally, the committee is exploring ways to recover the owed rent and ensure that future tenants are more reliable. This situation highlights the challenges of public-private partnerships and the importance of holding companies accountable for their commitments.

Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, and a customer service evaluation for all its licensed taxi and private hire drivers. This move is part of TfL's broader initiative to enhance passenger safety and improve the overall quality of transport services in London. The proposed assessments aim to ensure that drivers have the necessary language proficiency to communicate effectively with passengers, the ability to navigate the city efficiently, and the skills to provide excellent customer service.

The consultation process will involve gathering feedback from various stakeholders, including drivers, passengers, and industry representatives. If implemented, these new requirements could have significant implications for the thousands of drivers operating within London's transport network. TfL believes that these measures will contribute to a safer, more reliable, and customer-friendly transport environment, aligning with their commitment to maintaining high standards across all modes of public transportation in the capital.

The Saddlers looked more likely to take the lead in the first half, with Albion goalkeeper Jon McLaughlin keeping out Paul Downing and Romaine Sawyers with smart saves. Despite the Saddlers' efforts to push forward and create scoring opportunities, Albion's backline remained solid, and McLaughlin continued to impress with crucial saves. The 10 trees have been nominated by members of the public for the competition run by the Woodland Trust charity. A public vote will decide the winner, which will be named the UK's Tree of the Year. The nominated trees are located across the country and vary in species and age, each with its own unique story and historical significance. Some of the contenders include an ancient oak tree that has stood for over 500 years, a horse chestnut tree that served as a meeting point during World War II, and a yew tree believed to be one of the oldest living organisms in the UK. The Woodland Trust hopes that the competition will raise awareness about the importance of preserving these natural treasures and inspire people to take action to protect and care for trees in their own communities. The winner will be announced later this year, and will go on to represent the UK in the European Tree of the Year competition.

Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales were reported to be failing to adequately address issues such as stalking, harassment, and coercive control. The study highlighted the need for better training and resources to help police recognize and respond to these often-hidden forms of abuse. Victims of such crimes can suffer significant psychological harm, and the consequences can be just as severe as those of physical violence. The research recommended that police forces implement more comprehensive training programs to ensure officers are equipped to identify and manage all forms of domestic abuse. It also called for improved collaboration between police and other agencies to provide a more holistic approach to supporting victims. It is crucial that law enforcement agencies take these recommendations seriously and work to improve their response to all forms of domestic abuse, in order to better protect vulnerable individuals and prevent further harm.

The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house and is now being considered by the upper house. If approved, it would mark a significant shift in Japan's post-war pacifist policy, which has limited its military to self-defense operations within its own borders. The government argues that the changes are necessary to address new security challenges in the region, such as the rise of China and North Korea's nuclear ambitions. However, the move has been met with strong opposition both domestically and internationally. Critics argue that it could lead to Japan becoming embroiled in foreign conflicts and undermine its pacifist constitution. Protests have erupted across the country, with thousands of people taking to the streets to voice their opposition. The decision is expected to have far-reaching implications for Japan's role in regional and global security.

Aiden Webb, 22, from Norwich, set off to climb the Fansipan mountain alone on 3 June. He called his girlfriend to say he was in trouble after falling and hurting himself. Despite a major search operation involving local police, military personnel, and volunteers, Webb was found deceased on June 9th. The tragic incident has raised concerns about the safety of solo climbers and the importance of being well-prepared when undertaking such adventures. Webb, an experienced climber, had underestimated the terrain and the unpredictable weather conditions in the region. His story serves as a stark reminder of the risks associated with climbing and the need for proper planning, equipment, and communication. The climbing community has mourned his loss and urged others to learn from this incident to ensure their safety while pursuing their passion for climbing.

The site is believed to contain thousands of copies of a video game called ET The Extra-Terrestrial. A company called Atari made the game in the early 1980s, but it was a commercial failure and contributed to the video game industry crash of 1983. It is said that millions of unsold copies were buried in a landfill in Alamogordo, New Mexico. The site has since become a symbol of the excesses of the early video game industry and a cautionary tale for modern developers. In recent years, there have been efforts to excavate the site and recover the buried games. The excavation has attracted significant media attention and has been the subject of a documentary film. While some see it as an opportunity to reclaim a piece of video game history, others view it as a reminder of the industry's past mistakes. Regardless of one's perspective, the site serves as a fascinating example of how quickly fortunes can change in the world of technology and entertainment.

Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan, the Mayor of London, declared a state of emergency and urged residents to stay indoors unless absolutely necessary. The flooding was caused by torrential rain and the bursting of the River Lea's banks, leading to widespread damage and disruption. Emergency services worked tirelessly to rescue stranded residents and provide temporary shelter for those affected. Volunteers and community groups also came together to offer support and assistance to those in need. The aftermath of the flooding saw roads closed, public transport suspended, and power outages in some areas. Sadiq Khan emphasized the need for a review of the city's flood defenses and infrastructure to better prepare for future extreme weather events. He also called for increased investment in sustainable drainage systems and green infrastructure to help mitigate the impact of heavy rainfall and reduce the risk of flooding in the future. As the clean-up operation continues, the resilience and solidarity of the affected communities have been a source of inspiration for the entire city.

The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway, Scotland. This expansive artland spans 55 acres and is inspired by themes of space, astronomy and cosmology. The Crawick Multiverse is a testament to the imaginative reuse of a former open-cast coal mine, transforming it into a captivating landscape that draws visitors from all over the world.

The site features landforms, sculptures, and pathways that represent the universe and its various elements. Key features include the North-South Line, which is a dramatic stone avenue that aligns with the position of the sun during the solstices, and the Supercluster, a collection of large boulders that represent galaxies. Each element of the design has been carefully crafted to reflect the beauty and complexity of the cosmos.

The Crawick Multiverse is not only a stunning work of art but also an educational resource, offering workshops, guided tours, and events that explore the connections between art, science, and the environment. It is a place where visitors can experience the wonder of the universe

Disguised as police, they broke through a fence on Monday evening and broke into the cargo of a Swiss-bound plane to take the load of valuable goods inside. The robbers, who wore police uniforms and drove a vehicle with flashing lights, were able to deceive airport security and gain access to the restricted area. They quickly loaded several bags of high-value items, including jewelry and electronics, into their vehicle and fled the scene before authorities could respond.

The audacious heist has left airport officials and law enforcement agencies scrambling to understand how the robbers were able to so effectively impersonate police officers and breach airport security. The incident has raised serious concerns about the vulnerability of air cargo to theft and the need for improved security measures to protect valuable goods in transit. Investigators are currently reviewing surveillance footage and interviewing witnesses in an effort to identify and apprehend the culprits.

The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, once linked to smuggling, was visited by Treasure Island author Robert Louis Stevenson. Developer PegasusLife wants to replace it with a modern retirement complex, sparking controversy among local residents and historians. The proposed development includes demolishing the existing structure to make way for 74 luxurious apartments tailored to the elderly, complete with communal facilities such as a wellness center and a restaurant. PegasusLife argues that the new development will revitalize the area, providing high-quality housing options for seniors and boosting the local economy. However, opponents of the project contend that it would erase an important piece of local history and alter the character of the community. They are urging the developer to consider preserving the original building and incorporating it into the new design. The debate continues as the planning application progresses, with both sides eager to see their vision for the site come to fruition.
